 With Alcohol, the person who serves the alcohol may ask for ID, where a passport,student card or driver license can be used. If no ID is shown then you can be refused service. But usually you only get asked for ID if you look under 18 or in some places 21.
 
 With a credit card, we have a method of Chip and pin where you enter your pin number into the keypad once your card has been swiped, before that was introduced a signature was used to verify identity.
 
 To rent a movie, when you join a Rental shop you can produce 2 forms of ID such as a house hold Bill or a bank statement, then you can rent any movie you want as long as you meet that age restriction of the film.
 
 For Withdrawing money, you usually go to a cash machine(ATM) to lift money. But if you go into the branch they have a system similar to the chip and pin method of using credit cards.
 
 For Taking tests at uni you just produce your Student ID when you take the test.

You don't need an ID for medicine usually - you need a prescription, you can get someone else to pick it up for you. For alcohol they can refuse to serve you if they don't think you're 18, and there are various things you can prove your age with if it's a problem.
 
 Credit card you use a signature or a PIN given to you by the issuer. Rent a movie you use a card given to you by the video store, I use my student union card as it's a student union owned store. Applying for loans you use a combination of a variety of possible IDs, including Brith certificate, marriage certificate, bank statements, utility bills etc. Withdrawing cash from bank accounts it's usually signature or pin, as for credit cards. For large amounts they can ask for Birth certificate and/or other items as for loans. Taking tests at uni I use my uni Library Card, which has my photo and my library card number.
 
 The difference with all these is that they're not held by central government, they don't contain biometric information, or links to medical records, or whatever. They detail, at most, my name, contact details, date of birth, and what course I'm taking.

 The cost of the government's proposed biometric national ID card scheme will more than treble to £18bn, according to a report by experts at the London School of Economics (LSE).
